title: 107_hr1516
content: The "Campaign Finance Improvement Act of 2001" expands reporting requirements for certain contributions. The "Campaign Finance Improvement Act of 2001" expands reporting requirements for contributions of $200 or more, mandating political committees to notify the Commission within 10 days of receipt, including contributor identification, date, amount, candidate name, and office sought. This reporting is in addition to existing requirements under the Act. The "Campaign Finance Improvement Act of 2001" now requires expedited reporting for contributions of $200 or more to principal campaign committees, with notification to the Commission within 90 days of receipt. The "Campaign Finance Improvement Act of 2001" requires that a majority of contributions accepted by congressional candidates must come from in-state residents. The "Campaign Finance Improvement Act of 2001" mandates that at least 50% of contributions accepted by candidates for Senate or House elections must come from in-state individual residents. If a candidate spends over $250,000 of personal funds, this requirement does not apply to their opponents. The "Campaign Finance Improvement Act of 2001" requires that 50% of contributions to Senate or House candidates come from in-state individual residents. Contributions from political committees are allocated accordingly. Principal campaign committees must report this information in their first filing under subsection (a)(2) of the Act. The first report under subsection (a)(2) of the Campaign Finance Improvement Act of 2001 requires principal campaign committees to disclose total contributions received from in-state individual residents and all persons for the election period. Additionally, candidates must notify the Commission of the first expenditure of personal funds. Candidates must notify the Commission of expenditures or contributions exceeding $250,000 within 24 hours, including candidate details. Any candidate knowingly accepting contributions exceeding limits set by the Act will be fined 200 percent of the excess amount. Candidates who accept contributions exceeding limits set by the Act will be fined 200 percent of the excess amount, with interest assessed on unpaid fines after 30 days. SEC. 4 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to waive the "best efforts" exception for identifying contributors who donate over $200 in a calendar year. SEC. 5 lowers the threshold for cash contributions from $100 to $20. SEC. 6 addresses contributions by dependents not of voting age. Section 315(a) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include provisions regarding contributions made by dependent minors. The contribution made by a dependent minor will be treated as if made by the individual they are dependent on. The term 'dependent minor' refers to an individual who is dependent on another individual and has not reached the age of majority at the time of making the contribution. The amendment to Section 315(a) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 includes provisions for contributions made by dependent minors. A dependent minor is defined as an individual who is dependent on another person and has not reached the legal voting age at the time of making the contribution. SEC. 7 prohibits non-citizen individuals from contributing to federal elections. SEC. 8 outlines disclosure requirements for certain soft money expenditures of political parties. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include provisions regarding transfers of funds by national political parties and disclosure requirements by state political parties. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include new disclosure requirements for state political parties, stating that if a state political party committee is required to submit a report on its disbursements to a state or local government entity, it must also file a copy of the report with the Commission. SEC. 9. PROHIBITING INVOLUNTARY ASSESSMENT OF EMPLOYEE FUNDS FOR POLITICAL ACTIVITIES. The Federal Election Campaign Act is amended to prohibit national banks, corporations, and labor organizations from collecting dues or fees for political activities without individual authorization. The Federal Election Campaign Act is amended to prohibit national banks, corporations, and labor organizations from collecting dues or fees for political activities without individual authorization. The authorization remains in effect until revoked and can be revoked at any time. Political activity is defined as influencing elections, legislation, regulations, or educating individuals about candidates or laws. The amendment applies to amounts collected or assessed on or after the effective date. The amendment applies to amounts collected or assessed on or after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 10 prohibits authorized committees of candidates from accepting contributions from other candidates' committees, with an exception for transfers within the same candidate's committees. SEC. 11 mandates the FEC to provide software for electronic filing. SEC. 11 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to require the FEC to obtain computer software through competitive bidding for electronic filing. SEC. 12 mandates broadcasters to provide free response time to candidates affected by soft money ads. Section 317 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to prohibit broadcast stations from airing soft money advertisements featuring candidates for federal office unless they agree to provide free airtime for response ads from the candidate's authorized committee. The amendment to Section 317 of the Communications Act of 1934 prohibits broadcast stations from airing soft money advertisements featuring federal candidates unless they agree to provide free airtime for response ads from the candidate's authorized committee. Soft money advertisements are defined as those financed with funds not subject to the limitations of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. The term `candidate', `election', and `Federal office' are defined in the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. The amendments made by this Act will apply to elections and transactions after December 31, 2002.
